elements.content: The first anionic N-heterocyclic dicarbene, polymeric [:C{[N(2,6-Pri 2C6H3)]2CHCLi(THF)}] n 1, containing both normal (C2) and abnormal carbene (C4) centers in the same five-membered imidazole ring (III), has been prepared by lithiation of the imidazole monocarbene, :C{N(2,6-Pri 2C6H3)CH}2. The dicarbene nature of 1 was unambiguously demonstrated by the formation of the group 13 Lewis acid adducts (THF)2Li:C{[N(2,6-Pri 2C6H3)]2CHC(LA)}, where LA = AlMe3 [2·(THF) 2 ] and BEt3 [3·(THF) 2 ].
elements.clean_text: The first anionic N-heterocyclic dicarbene, polymeric [:C{[N(2,6-Pri 2C6H3)]2CHCLi(THF)}] n  1, containing both normal (C2) and abnormal carbene (C4) centers in the same five-membered imidazole ring (III), has been prepared by lithiation of the imidazole monocarbene, :C{N(2,6-Pri 2C6H3)CH}2. The dicarbene nature of 1 was unambiguously demonstrated by the formation of the group 13 Lewis acid adducts (THF)2Li:C{[N(2,6-Pri 2C6H3)]2CHC(LA)}, where LA = AlMe3 [2⋅(THF)  2 ] and BEt3 [3⋅(THF)  2 ].

elements.content: The quest for persistent carbenes rather than just transient divalent carbon intermediates was achieved by Bertrand’s (phosphino)(silyl)carbene and Arduengo’s imidazol-2-ylidene (I in Figure ). The subsequent rapid development of N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) chemistry has not only afforded extensive applications in organic and transition-metal homogeneous catalysis, but also resulted in novel advances involving main-group elements. In particular, a number of highly reactive molecules, including HBBH, a Ga6 octahedron, group 14 and 15 diatomic E2 species (E = Si, Ge, P, As), R2SiO, SiX2 (X = Br, Cl), P12, P2 2+, and PH, have all recently been stabilized using NHC ligands.
elements.clean_text: The quest for persistent carbenes rather than just transient divalent carbon intermediates was achieved by Bertrand's (phosphino)(silyl)carbene and Arduengo's imidazol-2-ylidene (I in Figure ). The subsequent rapid development of N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) chemistry has not only afforded extensive applications in organic and transition-metal homogeneous catalysis, but also resulted in novel advances involving main-group elements. In particular, a number of highly reactive molecules, including HBBH, a Ga6 octahedron, group 14 and 15 diatomic E2 species (E = Si, Ge, P, As), R2SiO, SiX2 (X = Br, Cl), P12, P2 2+, and PH, have all recently been stabilized using NHC ligands.

elements.content: Types of imidazole-based carbenes: (I) normal carbenes (NHCs); (II) abnormal carbenes (aNHCs); (III) anionic dicarbenes (NHDCs).
elements.clean_text: 1  Types of imidazole-based carbenes: (I) normal carbenes (NHCs); (II) abnormal carbenes (aNHCs); (III) anionic dicarbenes (NHDCs).

elements.content: Crabtree’s discovery of the first metal complexes involving “abnormal” carbenes (aNHCs; II in Figure ) initiated the study of these interesting species. Abnormal carbenes are kinetically and energetically (by 19 kcal/mol for the parent C3H4N2 species) less stable than their normal NHC isomers and exhibit stronger electron-donating capabilities. Notably, Bertrand recently succeeded in crystallizing both a viable metal-free aNHC and free mesoionic carbenes (MICs).
elements.clean_text: Crabtree's discovery of the first metal complexes involving "abnormal" carbenes (aNHCs; II in Figure ) initiated the study of these interesting species. Abnormal carbenes are kinetically and energetically (by 19 kcal/mol for the parent C3H4N2 species) less stable than their normal NHC isomers and exhibit stronger electron-donating capabilities. Notably, Bertrand recently succeeded in crystallizing both a viable metal-free aNHC and free mesoionic carbenes (MICs).

elements.content: In their five-membered imidazole rings, both NHCs (I) and aNHCs (II) have only one carbene center (C2 and C4, respectively). Is it possible to realize two carbene centers, at the C2 and C4 positions, in the same five-membered imidazole ring? Our recent synthesis of L′:P−H (L′: = :C{[N(2,6-Pri 2C6H3)]2CHCLi(THF)3}), coupled with Bertrand’s discovery of triazole biscarbene silver ionic polymers, suggested that metalation of the imidazole backbone may provide a convenient route to an anionic N-heterocyclic dicarbene (NHDC; III in Figure ). Although carbenes I, II, and III are all highly aromatic six-π-electron systems, anionic dicarbene III has both normal (C2) and abnormal (C4) carbene centers in the same five-membered imidazole ring. Herein we report the synthesis, molecular structure, and computational analysis of the first anionic N-heterocyclic dicarbene, [:C{[N(2,6-Pri 2C6H3)]2CHCLi}] n (1). The “dicarbene” character of 1 is unambiguously evident in the formation of group 13 Lewis acid (LA) adducts (THF)2Li:C{[N(2,6-Pri 2C6H3)]2CHC(LA)}, where LA = AlMe3 [2·(THF) 2 ] and BEt3 [3·(THF) 2 ]. Notably, 1 differs from anionic NHC ligands having only one carbene (C2) center.
elements.clean_text: In their five-membered imidazole rings, both NHCs (I) and aNHCs (II) have only one carbene center (C2 and C4, respectively). Is it possible to realize two carbene centers, at the C2 and C4 positions, in the same five-membered imidazole ring? Our recent synthesis of L':P-H (L': = :C{[N(2,6-Pri 2C6H3)]2CHCLi(THF)3}), coupled with Bertrand's discovery of triazole biscarbene silver ionic polymers, suggested that metalation of the imidazole backbone may provide a convenient route to an anionic N-heterocyclic dicarbene (NHDC; III in Figure ). Although carbenes I, II, and III are all highly aromatic six-π-electron systems, anionic dicarbene III has both normal (C2) and abnormal (C4) carbene centers in the same five-membered imidazole ring. Herein we report the synthesis, molecular structure, and computational analysis of the first anionic N-heterocyclic dicarbene, [:C{[N(2,6-Pri 2C6H3)]2CHCLi}] n  (1). The "dicarbene" character of 1 is unambiguously evident in the formation of group 13 Lewis acid (LA) adducts (THF)2Li:C{[N(2,6-Pri 2C6H3)]2CHC(LA)}, where LA = AlMe3 [2⋅(THF)  2 ] and BEt3 [3⋅(THF)  2 ]. Notably, 1 differs from anionic NHC ligands having only one carbene (C2) center.

elements.content: Dicarbene 1 was prepared in nearly quantitative yield (98%) by reaction of the NHC ligand L: (L: = :C{N(2,6-Pri 2C6H3)CH}2) with nBuLi in hexane at ambient temperature (Scheme ). When 1 is dissolved in a tetrahydrofuran/tetramethylethylenediamine (THF/TMEDA) solvent mixture, only a single THF moiety coordinates to each lithium cation to form 1·THF. The reaction of lithium metal with L: in THF gives 1·THF directly, albeit in a lower yield. Lithiation of L: by nBuLi in TMEDA gives 1·TMEDA. Compound 1·TMEDA is gradually converted into 1·THF upon dissolution in THF (Scheme ). Notably, compound 1 is persistent at ambient temperature under an argon atmosphere.
elements.clean_text: Dicarbene 1 was prepared in nearly quantitative yield (98%) by reaction of the NHC ligand L: (L: = :C{N(2,6-Pri 2C6H3)CH}2) with nBuLi in hexane at ambient temperature (Scheme ). When 1 is dissolved in a tetrahydrofuran/tetramethylethylenediamine (THF/TMEDA) solvent mixture, only a single THF moiety coordinates to each lithium cation to form 1⋅THF. The reaction of lithium metal with L: in THF gives 1⋅THF directly, albeit in a lower yield. Lithiation of L: by nBuLi in TMEDA gives 1⋅TMEDA. Compound 1⋅TMEDA is gradually converted into 1⋅THF upon dissolution in THF (Scheme ). Notably, compound 1 is persistent at ambient temperature under an argon atmosphere.

elements.clean_text: 1  Syntheses of the Anionic N-Heterocyclic Dicarbene 1

elements.content: The anionic character of 1 shifts the 1H NMR resonance of the imidazole ring upfield to 6.16 ppm in THF-d 8, relative to 7.19 ppm for its neutral NHC precursor. The X-ray structure shows that 1·THF exists as a polymeric chain in the solid state (Figure b). The asymmetric unit contains two :C{[N(2,6-Pri 2C6H3)]2CHCLi(THF)} units (Figure a). Each lithium cation is three-coordinate and adopts a trigonal-planar geometry. Besides its THF coordination, the lithium cation also binds ionically to two carbene centers: a C2 carbon [i.e., C(1) or C(28)] and a C4 carbon [i.e., C(30) or C(2)] from two neighboring NHDC units. The 2.175(6) Å Li(1)−C(1) and 2.216(6) Å Li(2)−C(28A) bond distances are somewhat longer than the Li(1)−C(30) [2.125(6) Å] and Li(2)−C(2) [2.122(6) Å] distances. These distances all compare well with reported Li−Ccarbene bond distances, which range from 2.093 to 2.339 Å.
elements.clean_text: The anionic character of 1 shifts the 1H NMR resonance of the imidazole ring upfield to 6.16 ppm in THF-d 8, relative to 7.19 ppm for its neutral NHC precursor. The X-ray structure shows that 1⋅THF exists as a polymeric chain in the solid state (Figure b). The asymmetric unit contains two :C{[N(2,6-Pri 2C6H3)]2CHCLi(THF)} units (Figure a). Each lithium cation is three-coordinate and adopts a trigonal-planar geometry. Besides its THF coordination, the lithium cation also binds ionically to two carbene centers: a C2 carbon [i.e., C(1) or C(28)] and a C4 carbon [i.e., C(30) or C(2)] from two neighboring NHDC units. The 2.175(6) Å Li(1)-C(1) and 2.216(6) Å Li(2)-C(28A) bond distances are somewhat longer than the Li(1)-C(30) [2.125(6) Å] and Li(2)-C(2) [2.122(6) Å] distances. These distances all compare well with reported Li-Ccarbene bond distances, which range from 2.093 to 2.339 Å.

elements.content: The HOMO and HOMO-2 of 1·THF (Figure ) correspond to the two strongly polarized Li−C bonding orbitals at the C2 and C4 carbon centers. Natural bond orbital (NBO) analysis documents the ionic bonding character of the Li−C bonds in 1·THF; the Wiberg bond indices of the Li−C bonds are 0.1, and the natural charges of Li+ are +0.84. These data support the anionic character of the NHDC fragment in 1·THF.
elements.clean_text: The HOMO and HOMO-2 of 1⋅THF (Figure ) correspond to the two strongly polarized Li-C bonding orbitals at the C2 and C4 carbon centers. Natural bond orbital (NBO) analysis documents the ionic bonding character of the Li-C bonds in 1⋅THF; the Wiberg bond indices of the Li-C bonds are 0.1, and the natural charges of Li+ are +0.84. These data support the anionic character of the NHDC fragment in 1⋅THF.

elements.content: The anionic dicarbene nature of 1 was demonstrated by its reaction with the group 13 Lewis acids AlMe3 and BEt3. Crystallization of the resulting reaction products in THF afforded 2·(THF) 2 and 3·(THF) 2 , respectively, as colorless crystals (Scheme ).
elements.clean_text: The anionic dicarbene nature of 1 was demonstrated by its reaction with the group 13 Lewis acids AlMe3 and BEt3. Crystallization of the resulting reaction products in THF afforded 2⋅(THF)  2  and 3⋅(THF)  2 , respectively, as colorless crystals (Scheme ).

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch2" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>2</label>
<caption>
<title>Reactivity Study of Polymeric <bold>1</bold>
</title>
</caption>
<graphic id="gs2" orientation="portrait" position="anchor" xlink:href="ja-2010-06631r_0004.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

X-ray structural analyses (Figure ) reveal that the AlMe3 and BEt3 Lewis acids cleave the Li−C4 bonds and bind to the aNHC centers (i.e., C4 carbons) of 1. The remaining Li+ is coordinated to the NHDC ligand at the “normal” (C2) carbon as well as to two THF molecules (Figure ). The formation of 2·(THF) 2 and 3·(THF) 2 clearly exhibits the “dicarbene” character of 1. Moreover, the reaction of 1 with excess AlMe3 or BEt3 still gives the same product 2·(THF) 2 or 3·(THF) 2 , respectively [i.e., insertion of a second Lewis acid into the Li−Ccarbene (C2) bond does not occur]. This observation suggests that the interaction between the Li+ cation and the anionic carbene is relatively strong. Indeed, the C(1)−Li(1) distances [2.094(6) Å for 2·(THF) 2 ; 2.096(4) Å for 3·(THF) 2 ] are among the shortest Li−Ccarbene bond lengths. 3·TMEDA was prepared by combining 1·TMEDA with BEt3 in toluene (Scheme ) and has a structure similar to that of 3·(THF) 2 .
elements.clean_text: X-ray structural analyses (Figure ) reveal that the AlMe3 and BEt3 Lewis acids cleave the Li-C4 bonds and bind to the aNHC centers (i.e., C4 carbons) of 1. The remaining Li+ is coordinated to the NHDC ligand at the "normal" (C2) carbon as well as to two THF molecules (Figure ). The formation of 2⋅(THF)  2  and 3⋅(THF)  2  clearly exhibits the "dicarbene" character of 1. Moreover, the reaction of 1 with excess AlMe3 or BEt3 still gives the same product 2⋅(THF)  2  or 3⋅(THF)  2 , respectively [i.e., insertion of a second Lewis acid into the Li-Ccarbene (C2) bond does not occur]. This observation suggests that the interaction between the Li+ cation and the anionic carbene is relatively strong. Indeed, the C(1)-Li(1) distances [2.094(6) Å for 2⋅(THF)  2 ; 2.096(4) Å for 3⋅(THF)  2 ] are among the shortest Li-Ccarbene bond lengths. 3⋅TMEDA was prepared by combining 1⋅TMEDA with BEt3 in toluene (Scheme ) and has a structure similar to that of 3⋅(THF)  2 .

elements.content: Functionalization of the C4 carbon of an NHC, which may allow tuning of the electronic and steric properties of the normal carbene center (C2), is a fascinating concept. In addition to its intriguing “dicarbene” applications, compound 1 may also provide a convenient synthetic route to a variety of C4-functionalized NHCs. The fact that the reaction of 1 with Me3SiCl affords :C{[N(2,6-Pri 2C6H3)]2CHC(SiMe3)} (4) in 82% yield (Scheme ) illustrates this promising utility of 1.
elements.clean_text: Functionalization of the C4 carbon of an NHC, which may allow tuning of the electronic and steric properties of the normal carbene center (C2), is a fascinating concept. In addition to its intriguing "dicarbene" applications, compound 1 may also provide a convenient synthetic route to a variety of C4-functionalized NHCs. The fact that the reaction of 1 with Me3SiCl affords :C{[N(2,6-Pri 2C6H3)]2CHC(SiMe3)} (4) in 82% yield (Scheme ) illustrates this promising utility of 1.
